nodes.text: Whether intergenerational income mobility in the United States has declined for recent birth cohorts and if the US remains a land of opportunity

The joint distribution of parent and child income can be decomposed into the copula (joint ranks) and the marginal income distributions; changes in mobility must distinguish changes in the copula from changes in the marginals

Population-based linked parent-child tax records (1996-2012) for children born 1980-1993 cover nearly the whole population with about 95 percent parent linkage; Statistics of Income (SOI) stratified samples cover 1971-1982 cohorts representing about 88 percent after weighting

Key variable definitions: parent family income = mean family income when child ages 15-19 (population sample) or family income in linkage year (SOI); child income = mean family income at ages 26 or 29-30; college attendance = 1098-T at age 19

The copula (rank-based relationship between parent and child income) has not changed over time: rank-rank slopes are approximately 0.30 for 1971-1982 cohorts and show no trend for cohorts through 1993

For recent cohorts, the college attendance gradient (difference in college enrollment between children of lowest- and highest-income parents) is essentially constant at about 74.5 percent for 1984-1989 cohorts and falls slightly to 69.2 percent by 1993

A consolidated series combining age 29-30 income, age 26 income (rescaled), and college attendance (rescaled) for 1971-1993 cohorts is virtually flat with estimated trend âˆ’0.0006 per year (no meaningful decline in mobility)
Transition probabilities are stable across cohorts: e.g., probability of a child from bottom parental quintile reaching the top quintile is 8.4 percent in 1971 and 9 percent in 1986 with little trend
Marginal income distributions widened substantially: inequality rose over time as measured by Gini coefficients and top 1 percent shares for parents and children

Large and persistent regional differences in mobility exist: bottom-to-top quintile probabilities vary from about 4 percent in parts of the Southeast to over 12 percent in Mountain states; regional rank-rank slopes and college gradients are stable but differ across divisions
Conclusion: Rank-based intergenerational mobility in the United States remained stable for children born 1971-1993 despite rising income inequality

Consequence: Because marginal inequality increased while rank mobility stayed constant, the economic consequences of the 'birth lottery' (differences due to parental income) have grown larger over time

Rank-rank specification: rank child income within cohort and rank parent income within cohort, then regress child rank on parent rank; this measure depends purely on the copula and is robust to life-cycle measurement

Limitation and open question: Despite widening early-life gaps in test scores, inputs, and social connectedness, mobility did not decline, leaving an unresolved question about which offsetting forces (e.g., civil rights gains or greater access to higher education) explain the stability
